refnamediv.refpurpose: populate various private-mount parts of the filesystem

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: make-private-fs is a chain-loading utility that mounts private volumes in various parts of the filesystem namespace and pre-populates them, and then chain loads to next-prog with the execvp3 function.
next-prog may contain its own command line options, which make-private-fs will ignore.
The parts of the filesystem that are mounted and populated are controlled by command-line options as follows:

listitem.para: Empty directories, held below a superuser-only-accessible parent, are mounted at /tmp and /var/tmp. They have rwx permissions for the owner, group, and world; and they have the sticky bit set.

A tmpfs filesystem is mounted at /dev, without any real devices in it. It is populated only with "API" devices such as /dev/shm. On Linux, a devpts filesystem is mounted at /dev/pts. On BSD systems, a fdescfs filesystem is mounted at /dev/fd.

This is causes empty directories, held below a superuser-only-accessible parent, to be mounted at various user home directories, or collections of user home directories. It is currently equivalent to --hide /home, --hide /run/user, and --hide /root. Note that pseudo-user home directories such as /var/lib/rabbitmq, /var/lib/qmail, and /var/lib/mysql are not covered by this, as they are not considered to hold an individual real user's private files.
Empty directories, held below a superuser-only-accessible parent, are mounted at directory. They have rwx permissions for the owner, and no permissions for anyone else.

refsection.para: The command will fail if the process is not running under the aegis of the superuser, because most of the internal operations necessary are not permitted to non-superusers.

refsection.title: Usage
refsection.para: make-private-fs is usually run chain-loaded from unshare1. Beware: Running it without unsharing first will affect the global mount namespace.
